John Arrowwood wrote:

>Up to generation 832.
>
>Discovered something relevant to anyone who is working in a domain with a 
>non-deterministic fitness evaluation.  Originally, I was calculating 
>stagnation by keeping track of the highest fitness value ever acheived for 
>that topology.  However, since there is a certain amount of randomness to 
>the fitness evaluation, there is a problem with that approach.  At one 
>point, there may be an uncharacteristically high single fitness value.  For 
>the next hundred generations it may be making steady progress without ever 
>exceeding that single peak value.  Thus, it is deemed 'stagnant' and killed 
>off.  Oops!
>  
>
Yeh, in my experience this is an often encountered problem. I've 
tinkered with solutions similar to your's of averaraging past fitness 
scores, and although I've never been entirely happy with it I think it's 
the best way of solving the problem if no appropriate deterministic 
evaluation is available.

Actually I've been quietly working on Tic-Tac-Toe, following in Derek 
and Philips footsteps, and this has come up again. I started out with 
mostly deterministic strategies for the opponents but the evolved NN's 
quickly take advantage of the fact that, say, a given strategy will 
always make a certain move in a given scenario, so although the NN's 
achieve good scores quickly they aren't very good when playing against 
other opponents, e.g. me :)

So I thought maybe I should introduce an element of randomness, but then 
I encounter the problem of some NN's getting an unrepresenitive score 
through good or bad luck. Another ay of minimising this problem is to 
play more games per evaluation, which has the same or similar effect as 
averaging scores from previous evals.


Colin
